subNodes.conversationText: root

<FirstName> found the source of the smell. The body of a young man was leaning against a natural pillar. His stomach had begun to rot away, but his head was still intact. His clothes -- fine clothes -- were stained with blood. He had a big gash in his neck.
<FirstName> was curious about the young man's identity. <He/She> looked carefully at his face and clothing.

He was in his mid-twenties, maybe, and had the look of someone who spent most of his life indoors. Though good-looking, he was slight, wispy. He wore an embroidered doublet and jerkin soiled through with blood and grime.
[Continue.]
On his finger was a ring. It had a thin gold band and one unfaceted, cloud-blue gem.
<FirstName> took the ring. What good could the trinket do this corpse?
Pharaoh, meanwhile, had hopped closer to the corpse's entrails and was cocking his head and whining. <FirstName> shooed the bird away.
Witches tend to be more practical and less squeamish than other people. <He/She> searched the corpse for other valuables.
He had no money on him, but <FirstName> did find a discordium-infused dagger in a sheath on his belt.
<He/She> took it.
Pharaoh nudged <FirstName>. "If I'm not going to eat," he seemed to be saying, "I'd prefer the open air."
[Wisdom] <FirstName> was almost ready to go, but <he/she> still wondered how the body ended up here.
[Success] He'd had his throat cut before he fell into the hole, that much was clear.
[Continue.]
Meanwhile, the blood on the floor above suggested his body had been pushed or dragged to the hole.
Still, <FirstName> concluded that he must not have been dead when he was thrown in.
He was sitting against a pillar, after all. He must have regained consciousness and rested against it as he bled out. He would have been too weak to look for an exit.
[Continue.]

Then the young witch bethought self of the other mystery: Who killed this person and why?

Was the Congress of Moths responsible? If the old stories were true, no -- the fairies took their victims to the roots of the world to devour them in the feast halls of the Wooden Crone. The pit beneath the shack was deep, but not that deep.
That meant he must have been dead when he was thrown in.

Of course, that conclusion didn't explain how he ended up propped against the natual pillar. But such details escape people in far less grim circumstances, and we shouldn't blame the young witch too much.
[Continue.]

Then the young witch bethought self of the other mystery: Who killed this person and why?

Was the Congress of Moths responsible? If the old stories were true, no -- the fairies took their victims to the roots of the world to devour them in the feast halls of the Wooden Crone. The pit beneath the shack was deep, but not that deep.
Beyond that, it was hard to say.

Was the Congress of Moths responsible? If the old stories were true, no -- the fairies took their victims to the roots of the world to devour them in the feast halls of the Wooden Crone. The pit beneath the shack was deep, but not that deep.
[Continue.]
Perhaps the murderous hunter had other victims.
<FirstName> left the body.
[Failure] The precise details of the man's demise eluded <him/her>, but <he/she> doubted they mattered,
